column4: On the GUI I can only create some forms of partition with a couple of different filesystem. How do I create the root partition?
the root partition has nothing more than being mounted on /
So that means it would be created "by its own"? And what about the partition names? I can't change them either. They just get a default name like "New Partiton #1"...
huh, don't play with your root part in Gparted :) and the New Partition #1 is just temporary .. partitions are NOT named by you :)
these aren't partitions names but mount points -- that's a totally different concept :)

the root (/) partition can't be changed in Gparted because you can only remount it in single-user mode .. and btw, why would you want to change your / ? it requires a good understanding of how the OS works
not always, some people make a /boot partition
Will the swap have to be created at that place? That is where I create the partitions?
what do you mean? you have to create the swap by yourself
Yes. At the installation process, you can choose to partition the hd manually, is it there where the swap has to be created?
if you do it manually, yes
So how do I create /usr, /var, /home and ect..? Aren't they partitions?
you could see them as partitions, but there are two different concepts here
it is the directory onto which you'll "mount" a partition
this has nothing to do with "Linux"
what's your desktop environment? (gnome, kde or xfce)
blame KDE; I don't help with KDE
